maml:description.maml:para: Formats and stylizes PowerShell commands output using HTML and Bootstrap.
Converts the output of PowerShell commands, passed by pipeline, to HTML format and adds Bootstrap style classes.

Depending on the set of parameters, the output can be converted to table format, card format, or raw (no style). If no parameters are set, by default it is converted to table format. In essence, it is like "ConverTo-Html -Fragment" PowerShell cmdlet but with Bootstrap styling built-in and another features.
Command or object to be formated in HTML, passed by pipeline.
Set this parameter to display a dark table.
...
Set this parameter to display a table with dark header.
...
Set this parameter to display a striped table.
...
Set this parameter to display a hoverable rows table.
...
Command or object to be formated in HTML, passed by pipeline.
Specifies a number, between 1 and 6, to display the command output in Bootstrap card style. The number specified is the number of cards displayed per row.

This parameter only displays the first two properties of the object passed. The first one will be dipslayed as the card title, the second will be the card text. (See the cards section of the Bootstrap v4.6 documentation for more info about card layout)
Command or object to be formated in HTML, passed by pipeline.
Set this parameter to display output in HTML format but without style.
Command or object to be formated in HTML, passed by pipeline.
Set this parameter to display a dark table.
...
Set this parameter to display a table with dark header.
...
Set this parameter to display a striped table.
...
Set this parameter to display a hoverable rows table.
...
Specifies a number, between 1 and 6, to display the command output in Bootstrap card style. The number specified is the number of cards displayed per row.

This parameter only displays the first two properties of the object passed. The first one will be dipslayed as the card title, the second will be the card text. (See the cards section of the Bootstrap v4.6 documentation for more info about card layout)
Set this parameter to display output in HTML format but without style.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-Process | Select-Object Cpu, Name | Format-Html -Darkheader -Striped -Hover ...
CPU Name
1475,09375 msedge.exe
0,671875 explorer.exe

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-Service | Select-Object Status, DisplayName | Format-Html -Cards 3
Stopped

AJRouter

Running

ALG

...

maml:description.maml:para: Gets credential information from form.
Gets the information sent by the form generated by "Write-CredentialForm" function.
Returns a PSCredential object with the username and password encrypted. Same as with PowerShell "Get-Credential" cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-CredentialForm
UserName Password -------- -------- Administrator System.Security.SecureString

maml:description.maml:para: Redirects to another URL passed by parameter.
Redirects, without user intervention, to another location, passing the URL by parameter.
Specifies the URL to be redirected to.
Specifies the URL to be redirected to.
Sets the web page title.
Sets the web page title. Override the current title for this page (set in Show-PSWebGui function). Only for web page title, not for window title.
Specifies the title to set.
Specifies the title to set.
Displays a styled graphical user interface (GUI) for PowerShell from an object passed with HTML and PowerShell content.
Starts a simple web server, listening on localhost, to display the structure and content passed within an object.
By default, it shows up a very simple web browser in a WPF window to display the content passed by parameter.

The content can be a string, an HTML page, cmdlets, functions or complex powershell scripts. The HTML content will be stylized with Bootstrap CSS framework. The server can execute and display local HTML or PS1 files. Custom CSS and Javascript are also compatible.
POST and GET methods are available and can be accesses by $_POST[] and $_GET[] variables, just like within PHP.
Specifies the object with the structure and content to display in the GUI.

The way to define custom routes with associated HTML and PowerShell content is through a hash table and scriptblocks whitin it. The hash table are made up of keys and their associated values. Keys are custom defined relative paths, and must always start with
; values are strings, HTML and PowerShell scripts enclosed within a scriptblock.
This is an example of a GUI structure passed as an input object:
$routes=@{
\<a href='showProcesses'\>\<h2\>Show Running Processes\</h2\>\</a\>
\<a href='/showServices'\>\<h2\>Show Running Services\</h2\>\</a\>
"/showProcesses" = { Get-Process | Select-Object name, cpu | Format-Html }
"/showServices" = {
\<div\>
\<h1\>Services\</h1\>
Get-Service | Select-Object Name, Status | Where-Object Status -eq "Running" | Format-Html
Specifies TCP port number to listen to. Default 80.
Specifies the window title and the HTML page title.

Specifies the path for the icon used on the window and on the HTML page. This path can be absolute or relative to the document root. If the path is not within the document root, it will only be displayed on window.
Specifies the CSS URI to use in addition to Bootstrap. It can be a local file or an Internet URL. It can not be relative path, must be absolute.
Specifies the root path for the files that the server will access. Do not put final slash. Default $PWD
Set this parameter to not display a web browser in a WPF window. The content can only be viewed within a third-party web browser.
Set this parameter to not display <html>, <head>, <meta>, <link>, <style> and <body> tags. With this option, the content will not be formated.
Specifies the object with the structure and content to display in the GUI.

The way to define custom routes with associated HTML and PowerShell content is through a hash table and scriptblocks whitin it. The hash table are made up of keys and their associated values. Keys are custom defined relative paths, and must always start with
; values are strings, HTML and PowerShell scripts enclosed within a scriptblock.
This is an example of a GUI structure passed as an input object:
$routes=@{
\<a href='showProcesses'\>\<h2\>Show Running Processes\</h2\>\</a\>
\<a href='/showServices'\>\<h2\>Show Running Services\</h2\>\</a\>
"/showProcesses" = { Get-Process | Select-Object name, cpu | Format-Html }
"/showServices" = {
\<div\>
\<h1\>Services\</h1\>
Get-Service | Select-Object Name, Status | Where-Object Status -eq "Running" | Format-Html
Specifies TCP port number to listen to. Default 80.
Specifies the window title and the HTML page title.

Specifies the path for the icon used on the window and on the HTML page. This path can be absolute or relative to the document root. If the path is not within the document root, it will only be displayed on window.
Specifies the CSS URI to use in addition to Bootstrap. It can be a local file or an Internet URL. It can not be relative path, must be absolute.
Specifies the root path for the files that the server will access. Do not put final slash. Default $PWD
Set this parameter to not display a web browser in a WPF window. The content can only be viewed within a third-party web browser.
Set this parameter to not display <html>, <head>, <meta>, <link>, <style> and <body> tags. With this option, the content will not be formated.

dev:type.maml:name: Debug and Verbose modes write request and response information to the console.

maml:description.maml:para: Displays an example GUI.
Displays a basic GUI example to show how this module runs. This funtion returns the object with the structure and content used to display the graphical interface.
Writes and displays a web page with basic form to enter credentials.
Writes and displays a web page with a basic form to enter credentials. The form has user and password inputs and a submit button.
By default, the function writes the labels for the inputs and the button, form title and description, but this is all customizable using parameters.
Because credentials will be sent with this form, the method is always POST, it can not be modified. The POST variables for the inputs are $_POST["userName"] and $_POST["Password"].
This form is the HTML+Bootstrap version of PowerShell "Get-Credential" cmdlet.
Specifies a title for the form. This title will appear as
tag at the top of the form. The web page title will be modified too.
Specifies a description for the form. This description will appear as
tag at the top of the form.
Specifies the action attribute. This is the URL where the form will send the data.
Specifies a label for the username input.
Specifies a label for the password input.
Specifies a label for the submit button.
Specifies the action attribute. This is the URL where the form will send the data.
Specifies a description for the form. This description will appear as
tag at the top of the form.
Specifies a label for the password input.
Specifies a label for the submit button.
Specifies a title for the form. This title will appear as
tag at the top of the form. The web page title will be modified too.
Specifies a label for the username input.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Write-CredentialForm -Action "/login"

Credential input

Enter your credential

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Write-CredentialForm -Action "/login" -Title "Login form" -Description "Please, enter your credential to log into the system"

Login form

Please, enter your credential to log into the system

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Write-CredentialForm -Action "/login" -Title "Login form" -Description "Please, enter your credential to log into the system" -UsernameLabel "Enter your computer login username" -PasswordLabel "Enter your computer login password" -SubmitLabel "Login"

Login form

Please, enter your credential to log into the system
